utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: This is an easy one. You love this guy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Come on, he’s an under-appreciated genius.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Still think it’s me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: It’s not you. Now think, there’s a car named after him.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course there is. The Mini Cooper, ’cause it’s me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: How about this, he’s a poor man’s Sheldon Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, Tesla.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hey, how did it go?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, not fun. The doctor shoved a camera up into my sinuses.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, I watched. It was like the scary boat tunnel in Willy Wonka.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Did they figure out what’s wrong?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah. It’s a deviated septum. The surgery to correct it is simple. He’s gonna do it next week.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why would you have surgery?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Because I can’t breathe. I snore, I get sinus infections.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, back off, he’s all mine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But you don’t have a life-threatening condition. Why would you take the risk of surgery?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, it’s a routine procedure, I’ve heard you complain about his snoring.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, for the first five or six years, but I’ve gotten used to it. It helps me sleep. He’s like my mucus-powered white noise machine.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I’m gonna get the surgery, it’s no big deal. End of story.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Very well. I’m done talking about it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I believe it was your turn in the game.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Let’s see. Oh, this person is most famous for never having gotten his nose mutilated with elective surgery and never living the rest of his life in the shadows as a hideous, disfigured freak.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I think you could give a better clue.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t. I’m not even sure if that’s a person or a typo.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, why?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m listening to you snore. I’m wondering how I’ll ever sleep without it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If it helps you sleep, then why are you sitting here staring at me like the albino boogeyman?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really Leonard. Insults? After I spent two hours in your closet, waiting for you to fall asleep?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s your problem?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If the surgery is successful, the snoring is gone. And if you die during surgery, the snoring is gone.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It sounds like either way, I finally get some rest.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I have to be honest with you Leonard, I’m truly worried.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I told you, there’s nothing to worry about.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I’ve been doing some research and I’ve learned that one in 700,000 people die from general anaesthesia.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Buddy, wh, do you realize that that also means 699,999 people don’t die?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I suppose that’s true. You’re such a glass half-full kind of guy. I’m going to miss that.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, so, my, uh, parents’ 40th anniversary’s coming up and I can’t think of a thing to get them.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Damn, can you imagine being married to someone for 40 years?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Not anymore.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Anyway, any ideas on a gift?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, what are some of the things they like?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: They used to like going to the Mumbai Symphony, but last year my mom thought they were phoning it in. Then my dad said based on their love life, she should know about phoning it in.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: He said that to her?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Well, they weren’t speaking at the time, so he had a servant say it to her. Oh, maybe I could make a gift for them. I know how much you guys love the coasters I made for you.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: They’re yours in the divorce.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey. What’re you working on?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Remember when I said if you went through with your surgery, there was a one-in-700,000 chance of dying?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I’ve been crunching the numbers, and so far, I’ve gotten your probability of death all the way to a sphincter-tightening one in 300.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Great timing. My check sphincter light just went on.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, what if you have an allergic reaction to the surgeon’s latex gloves?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m not allergic to latex.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, then why don’t you wear the rubber gloves I bought for you to do the dishes?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: For the same reason I don’t wear the apron or the hair net.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fine. What about epilepsy?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t have epilepsy, either.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You don’t, but the surgeon might, hmm? And your carotid artery is just one shaky scalpel away from becoming the dancing fountain at Disneyland.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, do you realize that driving is riskier than surgery?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I do. I have the drive to the hospital right here. That is if you make it to the car without falling down the stairs. And don’t expect me to carry you, I do that enough in life.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Buddy, I, I get that you’re worried about me and I, I appreciate that, but I’m not going to die.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You don’t know that.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, I do know that it won’t be from an asteroid strike.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know who else said that? Every cocky T. Rex currently swimming around in the gas tank of your car.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If there was an asteroid strike, wouldn’t you die, too?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t know, I’m smart and scrappy, I think I’d find a way.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Tell you what, the surgery’s not for a week, I’ll think about it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you. And while you’re thinking about it, if you have the surgery in Nicaragua during monsoon season, I can practically guarantee your death.

utterance.speaker: Raj (on phone)
utterance.content: Yes. Okay. I, I understand. Of course, yes. I’ll call you tomorrow. Bye.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So I found this fencing school in Burbank that has a Jedi class. And if you’re cool being the only adults there, they said they are.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Dude, my parents just split up.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Uh, that was my dad on the phone. He moved out.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, my God, I, I’m sorry. I mean, if you’re not up to it, we don’t have to go out, we can just hang here.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, it’s fine. It’s not that big a deal. As long as they’re happy, I’m happy. And when I get to see them for the holidays, I’ll get to celebrate Diwali twice, one at each house. That’s double the Diwali.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You sure you’re okay?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m okay.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You don’t look okay.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: How can I be okay? I come from a broken home.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: The doctor said I should be out of surgery by ten.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay. And Sheldon really believes we’re at a public swimming pool?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: He was so busy figuring out how many parts per million of urine we’d be floating around in, he didn’t even question it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: 18 parts per million. And he’s still doing it.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Don’t worry about that. I’m happy to take you to work.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, thank you. And Leonard never lets me have French toast sticks in the car. I can’t have syrupy fingers, but he can do the backstroke in a toilet bowl.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: It’s nice they’re getting exercise.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Although now that I think about it, Leonard would never go swimming in public without his swim shirt.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m sure he brought it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, but last year, at Magic Mountain, he got such a bad sunburn, we had to cut him out of it.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: He probably got a new one. Finish your breakfast. Look, there’s an entire section of my dashboard that doesn’t have any syrup on it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re acting odd. Why?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m odd all the time, everyone knows that. Just last night I tried to see how many fava beans I could fit in my mouth.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Tell me the truth.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Twenty eight.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Come on.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Fifty six.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amy. What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: All right. Don’t get upset, but, an earlier appointment opened up for Leonard and he’s getting the surgery right now.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I see. Take me to Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Just go to work, he’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amy, he’s my best friend, and if you don’t take me, I’m going there anyway.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Fine. It’s sweet that you care about him so much.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I do. And I wouldn’t be able to forgive myself if something happened to him and I wasn’t at his bedside to say I told you so.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: We had a really nice swim.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, stop it. I assume this medical centre’s already treated the burns on your bottom from the recent pants fire.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: ‘Cause I’m a liar, liar?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s for the fire marshal to determine.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You had to tell him?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: He wore me down. And I was distracted, he has on extra baby powder today.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is he okay?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: He’s still in surgery.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Very well.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: He’s gonna be all right. That is sticky.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Come on, let’s talk about something other than the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s a good idea. Penny, did you and Leonard ever discuss funeral arrangements?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I think she meant something a little happier.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I suppose we could try to make it a celebration, but he died so young.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Knock, knock.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey. What brings you by?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, muffin much.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Told you, not funny.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: He’s just not laughing because he’s feeling blueberry. Tough crowd.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m sorry. This is very sweet. Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, how you doing?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Better. I guess the news just hit me a lot harder than I expected.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, of course. I would be devastated if my parents split up.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Why? Your father barely speaks to your mother.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, at least he stuck around, not like your dad, who just took off.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: As you can see, we’re here to cheer you up.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Sorry, Raj. Do you have any sense of what happened with your folks?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I think, over time, they started to resent each other, and instead of talking about the things that bothered them, they kept it bottled up, and the hate just grew.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: It’s a shame they spent all that time unhappy. But sometimes, there’s muffin you can do about it. You get it, right?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, it’s nice you got him that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, this isn’t for Leonard, no. Amy bought it for me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Stubbed his toe on the revolving door on the way in.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know those confounded things make me dizzy.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Who told you to keep going around?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There was a large plant in the lobby. It kept looking like the outside.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, listen, when Leonard comes out, he is not gonna feel great, so, please don’t give him a hard time.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Penny has a good point. This is like the man in the supermarket with the goiter on his neck. Whatever you’re thinking, just keep it to yourself.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It was like a grapefruit.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: And I’m sure he knew that before you held a grapefruit up next to it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I’m not making any promises. Not only did Leonard take what I feel is an unnecessary risk, he deceived me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, the reason he deceived you is you were being a pain in the ass.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The reason I was being a pain in the B is because I was worried about him, and no one else was.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Really? You won’t even say A?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You bet your sweet B I won’t.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Obviously, I care about Leonard. I’m gonna spend the rest of my life with him.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And I’m not? It’s an earthquake. I knew it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, it was just a little tremor.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A little tremor that turns routine sinus surgery into a frontal lobotomy. Oh, I don’t care for this at all. Oh, I need to see he’s okay.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, you can’t go back there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Try and stop me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why didn’t you stop me?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Can I tell you something? This whole thing with Raj’s parents just got me a little worried about us.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What are you talking about? We’re fine. And Raj’s parents probably split up because of Raj.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: They always say the children aren’t to blame, but, come on.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I’m not joking, Howie. You heard what he said about his parents. It was the little things they kept bottled up. I don’t want that to happen to us.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: How can I convince you it won’t?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, is there anything about me you’re keeping inside?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m not answering that. It’s a trap.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: So there are things you don’t like.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And here I am in the trap. You just keep talking. I’m gonna chew my leg off.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Just tell me one thing that bothers you, and I promise I won’t get mad.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay. The truth is, sometimes, you’re too beautiful.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh. Howie, be serious.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, okay. I really don’t like how your wings poke me when we sleep ’cause you’re an angel.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Okay, fine, maybe it was a bad idea.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I just don’t think the secret to a happy marriage is going out of our way to criticize each other. Although, there are ways to improve our communication. One thing I learned when I was in couples therapy was…

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Who were you in couples therapy with?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Not important.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Was it your mom?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Not important.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: It was your mom.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Anyway, the therapist had us tell each other what we loved about one another.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, that’s so sweet. I want to do that.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: All right.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Okay, um, I love that you make me laugh.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thank you. And I love that you’re strong and independent.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: And yet, I still love when you hold a door for me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I love that I’m kind of a slob around here, and you’re okay with that.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Uh-huh. And I love that I work and do all the cleaning, and you’re okay with that.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: See, I am. Isn’t this great?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Come on, smile. This is gonna be my Christmas card.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know this is all your fault.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How is it my fault?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I told you not to get the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, first of all, the surgery was a success, and secondly, I didn’t even want you there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wow. I don’t know which hurts worse, my nose or my heart. Well, I’m done speaking to you.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Don’t be like that. You two need to talk this out.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, ’cause you sound really funny.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I’m sorry I didn’t tell you about the surgery, but you were worried about nothing.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, you’re hardly out of the woods, no. You still run the risk of infection, a blood clot, the possibility that an inattentive surgeon let a barn spider lay eggs in your nose. The minute you sneeze web, I’m moving out.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I never thought I’d say these words, but come on, nose spider.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Who are you kidding? You were so panicked Leonard was gonna die, you’ll never leave him.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon will move out eventually.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, once he figures out how to work a door.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was not panicked, and I am not overly attached to Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You were so worried that you smashed your face trying to check on me. You love me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah. Tell me those aren’t the words of a man with a spider eating its way through his brain. Amy, you’re a neuroscientist. Crack his skull open, spray some Raid in there.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I love that you take pride in your looks, even when I have to pee in the morning, and you’re in there spending an hour on your hair.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I love that you’re too good to pee in the kitchen sink.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I love that you have the confidence to speak, even without giving it an ounce of thought.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And I love how your hair is always on the soap. It’s like washing myself with a hamster.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, guys. Sorry I am so late. I was on the phone with my mother.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, how is she?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Pretty good. She bought the book Eat, Pray, Love and used it to set my father’s Mercedes on fire. So, what’s up with you guys?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We’re just saying all the things we love about each other.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, like you and I did at couples therapy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, what’d you get?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I ordered it before your surgery. It’s the urn I was going to put you in.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, that’s morbid. Send it back.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can’t send it back, I had it engraved. Here lie the ashes of Leonard Hofstadter. He thought he was right, but his room mate knew better.”

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s funny. Boy, I’m gonna miss these painkillers.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, why did you get two? I’m with stupid.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, that one’s mine.
